《如何选择完美的微距镜头》一文首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是杰梅斯·登普西 (Jaymes Dempsey) 。

当我第一次对微距摄影感兴趣时，我知道我当时的主镜头（长焦变焦镜头）无法让我足够近地捕捉我所追求的细节水平。我还知道相机制造商提供了专门的微距镜头，这将使我能够放大拍摄对象并突出所有美丽的细节。

换句话说，我知道我需要一个微距镜头。

但当谈到选择最适合这项工作的微距镜头时，我迷失了方向。我最终决定在 eBay 上购买一支旧的 60mm f/2.8 镜头，不是因为我认为它非常适合我的用途，而是因为我没有太多钱可花，而且价格也可以接受。

距离我购买第一支镜头已经过去很长时间了。从那以后我升级了，再次升级，又升级了一些。事实上，多年来，我使用过无数来自不同相机品牌的微距镜头。现在，我对什么是“完美”微距镜头有了更好的认识，在这篇文章中，我将向您详细介绍。

最好的微距镜头是什么？

这似乎是一个简单的问题，但答案却相当复杂。这取决于许多因素，包括：

  • 物理要求（即，您想要更小、更便于手持的镜头，还是愿意使用需要三脚架的巨大镜头？）
  • 您的预算
  • 您喜欢的主题（微距类型涵盖多个主题，每个主题都有自己的挑战；例如，拍摄昆虫与拍摄花朵非常不同！）
  • 您喜欢的风格（如果您想拍摄印象派、近乎抽象的微距照片，您需要选择与拍摄整体清晰的照片不同的镜头）

换句话说，没有一种理想的微距镜头。然而，您可以使用一些基本准则来选择适合您需求的理想微距镜头，今天，我集中讨论三个主要考虑因素：图像质量、焦距和价格。

微距镜头和图像质量

在选择镜头时，摄影师通常关注图像质量，尤其是清晰度。

但我很高兴地告诉您，对于微距摄影来说，这通常不是什么问题。

为什么？微距镜头非常锐利。即使是价格范围较低的镜头也能提供专业级的清晰度，尤其是在稍微缩小光圈时。在我的摄影生涯中，我使用过很多微距镜头，而且我从未对清晰度水平感到不满意。我的一只微距镜头的其中一个玻璃元件上什至出现了真菌，但它仍然非常清晰。

然而，这并不意味着低端微距镜头与价格较高的镜头没有区别。昂贵的微距镜头通常可以提供更好的清晰度；只是起点要好很多。更昂贵的镜头也往往会产生更好的散景，这对于某些类型的微距摄影非常重要（例如我喜欢的浅景深微距照片，并且在整篇文章中都会展示）。

此外，低端微距镜头有时会出现色差问题（通常是图像高对比度部分出现紫边和黄边）。我购买的最便宜的微距镜头之一存在色差问题，尽管这个问题并不像听起来那么令人沮丧；我能够通过稍微缩小光圈来减少 CA，并且我还能够在后处理中将其删除。

也就是说，我确实更愿意尽可能避免色差。因此，当我在下面讨论不同的镜头时，我会注意到我遇到的任何色差问题。

微距镜头焦距

我将围绕焦距进行讨论；这是缩小潜在微距镜头范围的简单方法，因为焦距通常决定并限制您的微距摄影选择。

微距镜头可分为三个焦距类别：短焦距（35-60mm）、中焦距（80-105mm）和长焦距（150-200mm）。

短微距镜头（35-60mm）

  • 优点：重量轻、价格便宜
  • 缺点：散景不太令人印象深刻，工作距离较短（对昆虫不利）

短微距镜头往往用于更休闲的微距郊游，或者作为“通用镜头”，在需要时切换到微距。它们易于储存、携带，而且价格相当便宜。由于尺寸小，它们也更容易手持。

然而，短微距镜头的一大缺点是工作距离缩短。工作距离是指镜头末端到被摄物体的距离。为了使用 60mm 微距镜头进行高倍率摄影，拍摄对象必须非常靠近镜头。这可能会导致问题。首先，拍摄昆虫时通常需要一定的距离，因此通常不适合近距离拍摄。

此外，根据照明条件，您的头部（或相机）可能会在拍摄对象上投射不需要的阴影。较短的镜头也往往导致散景效果较差。

然而，如果您希望使用更便携的设备和强大的图像质量进行休闲微距摄影，那么较短的微距镜头可能适合您。我的第一支微距镜头的焦距为 60 毫米，虽然我确实需要近距离拍摄高倍率图像，但它的表现很好。如今，短微距镜头并不是我进行花卉或昆虫微距摄影的首选，但对于初学者来说，它是一个非常便宜的选择。另外，正如我上面提到的，您可以使用较短的微距镜头，而不仅仅是微距摄影；还可以使用更短的微距镜头。这些镜头也非常适合人像摄影、街头摄影、旅行摄影、静物摄影等。

那么哪种短微距镜头最好呢？当前 DSLR 系统的逐步淘汰和无反光镜系统的扩展使得快速推荐变得更加复杂，但以下是我的想法：

如果您是佳能 DSLR 拍摄者，您应该考虑佳能 EF-S 60mm f/2.8 USM ，这是一款出色的全能镜头，还提供出色的微距功能。 （但请注意，它是为 APS-C 相机设计的，而不是全画幅型号！）您可能需要在二手市场上购买它，价格可能会波动很大，但如果您有耐心，您可以得到很好的交易。

佳能无反光镜用户应该考虑佳能 RF 35mm f/1.8 IS ，它以合理的价格提供良好的光学性能，而且图像稳定性对于手持微距摄影非常有用。该镜头的最大缺点是缺乏真正的微距放大倍率，但 1:2 的放大倍率仍然能让您足够近地捕捉大量隐藏的细节。

尼康 DSLR 摄影师可能会关注尼康 40mm f/2.8G ，它兼容全画幅和 APS-C 相机，拥有真正的微距放大倍率，而且价格极低。

如果您是一名尼康 DSLR 摄影师，预算较多，您应该考虑尼康 60mm f/2.8G ，它的拍摄范围更大；它也可以在二手市场上以大幅降价出售。尼康无反光镜用户可以通过FTZ 适配器使用尼康 F 卡口（即 DSLR）镜头，但我鼓励您也看看尼康 Z MC 50mm f/2.8 镜头，它提供出色的光学性能、时尚的构造、和 1:1 对焦，尽管它比上面提到的镜头贵一点。

我还想简单提一下尼康 60mm f/2.8D ，它是我最喜欢的镜头，因为它是我购买的第一支微距镜头。目前，该镜头仅在二手市场上有售，但这对您有利，因为您可以以超低的价格购买它。它的锐度一直给我留下了深刻的印象。值得注意的是，自动对焦相当慢，但我在拍摄微距时总是使用手动对焦（你可能也应该这样做！），所以这不是问题。

如果您是索尼摄影师，您的微距选项可能会受到一些限制，但您仍然可以考虑一些不错的短微距镜头。有索尼 30mm f/3.5 ；对于大多数微距工作来说，它的长度都相当短，而且你很难用它来拍摄昆虫等主题，但作为一款也能近距离对焦的通用预算镜头，它是一个不错的选择。对于更专业的索尼微距摄影，我推荐索尼 50mm f/2.8 镜头，因为它具有更长的工作距离、更宽的最大光圈和坚固的结构。

中端微距镜头（80-105mm）

  • 优点：工作距离更大，价格便宜，散景效果很好，重量轻，有很多选择
  • 缺点：工作距离仍然相当短；高端中端微距镜头可能相当昂贵

中焦微距镜头是我个人最喜欢的微距镜头。它们是花卉摄影的绝佳选择，尤其是像我喜欢做的更抽象级别的花卉摄影。为什么？

首先，这些镜头相对较轻，这意味着即使在弱光下，我也可以毫无困难地手持它们。这允许更大的灵活性。

其次，中距微距镜头为花卉摄影提供了完美的工作距离。我喜欢与我正在拍摄的花朵保持中等距离——不要太近，以免我几乎碰到花朵，但也不要太远，以免其他花朵、叶子和树枝妨碍。

第三，这些镜头提供高质量的光学元件，但通常可以以相当低的价格找到，特别是如果您愿意从第三方制造商那里购买的话。例如，腾龙提供了一系列出色的 90mm 微距镜头，您通常可以以 400 美元或更少的价格找到它们。

如果您想做昆虫摄影，或者经常使用三脚架拍摄并需要足够的工作距离，我建议您使用更长的微距镜头。但是，如果您有兴趣进行手持花卉摄影，或者您的预算有限但想要更专用的微距镜头，我推荐中端型号。

第一个较便宜的选择是前面提到的腾龙 90mm 微距镜头。长期以来，我一直使用腾龙的这款90mm f/2.8镜头， 尼康和佳能都可用。虽然我偶尔会遇到色差问题，但清晰度、散景质量和价格足以弥补这一点。这个价位的另一个选择是适用于佳能和尼康的Tokina 100mm f/2.8 。

考虑中等价格：佳能无反光镜用户应该考虑RF 85mm f/2 ，它提供非常好的光学元件和异常宽的最大光圈（无论如何对于微距镜头来说）。我确实希望它能够达到真正的微距 1:1 放大倍率——而不是稍微不那么令人印象深刻的 1:2——但近焦性能仍然非常稳定。

我也喜欢佳能 EF 100mm f/2.8 USM 。您可能需要购买二手产品，但您可以找到一些价格非常合理的型号，并且 1:1 的放大功能和 100 毫米的工作范围非常适合拍摄自然特写镜头。

Sigma 还提供适用于佳能和尼康的105mm f/2.8 微距镜头，我广泛使用并喜爱它。构建质量是惊人的，虽然自动对焦不是特别快，但如果您使用手动对焦（我推荐），它会做得很好。

最后，在价格较高的方面，我们有两款 DSLR 镜头： 尼康 105mm f/2.8G VR和佳能 100mm f/2.8L IS 。尼康 105mm 很难找到新的，但如果你能找到一个好的二手镜头，你最终可能会以便宜的价格买到一支专业级镜头。

如果您是佳能无反光镜用户，您还可以选择购买佳能 RF 100mm f/2.8L IS 。它价格昂贵，但它包含了原始 Canon 100mm f/2.8L IS 的所有功能以及一些出色的新功能，例如 1.4 倍放大功能和球面像差控制环，可更好地控制散景质量。

尼康无反光镜用户应该选择Z MC 105mm f/2.8 VR S ，这是一款令人惊叹的中端微距镜头，非常适合微距专业人士和狂热爱好者。

最后，如果不提及索尼 90mm f/2.8，最佳中端微距镜头的列表就不完整。是的，它很昂贵，但构建质量非常出色，而且清晰度和散景非常适合专业品质的微距图像。

长微距镜头（150-200mm）

  • 优点：令人惊叹的工作距离，通常出色的散景和图像质量。
  • 缺点：重，通常非常昂贵，选择不多

较长的微距镜头往往具有令人惊讶的良好图像质量，但（通常）价格昂贵。例如，我花了很多时间使用Sigma 150mm f/2.8进行拍摄，散景质量和清晰度总是给我留下了深刻的印象。

这些较长的微距镜头还提供了最佳的工作距离，这对于昆虫摄影来说通常是必不可少的。

较长工作距离的另一个优点是您可以轻松使用流行的创意微距技术：通过失焦的花朵进行拍摄。

然而这些镜头相当重，这使得长时间手持变得困难，并且在弱光下几乎不可能。如果您想要进行高水平的昆虫摄影，或者如果您想要一流的图像质量并且不介意重量或价格，您会需要考虑这些镜头。

我推荐的长微距镜头清单包括价格合理的 Sigma 150mm （适用于佳能和尼康数码单反相机）。与此列表中的其他一些数码单反镜头一样，它有点难找到，但它提供出色的图像质量，并且像坦克一样构造。很长一段时间，我把它作为花卉摄影的备用微距镜头（我的佳能 100mm f/2.8L 是我的主镜头），当我想要更长的工作距离时，我转向它。 （最终，我意识到我太喜欢中端微距镜头的灵活性了，所以我卖掉了我的 Sigma 150mm，但有时我确实会怀念它！）

接下来，我们有较新的 Irix 150mm f/2.8 Macro，适用于尼康 F 卡口相机、 佳能 EF 卡口相机和索尼 E 卡口相机。我个人很喜欢 Irix 镜头，这款镜头的拍摄范围很广，价格也很实惠，但请务必记住，Irix 150mm 微距镜头不具备任何自动对焦功能。因此，虽然它作为手动对焦微距镜头表现良好，但您可能不会发现自己将它用于任何其他目的。

然后， 尼康 200mm f/4和佳能 180mm f/3.5L提供令人惊叹的图像质量和高价格。这两种型号都是为数码单反相机设计的，尽管无反光镜摄影师通过相应的数码单反相机安装到无反光镜安装适配器使用它们应该不会有问题。这两款镜头非常适合远距离微距摄影，如果您认真对待微距类型并且您希望比中距微距镜头能够提供更长的工作距离，您可能会发现它们物有所值。

选择完美的微距镜头：最后的话

虽然大多数微距镜头都可以拍摄高质量的图像，但不同的镜头会比其他镜头更好地满足某些需求。

总结一下：

  • 如果您正在寻找一款更通用的镜头来进行休闲微距拍摄，请选择一款短距镜头。
  • 但如果您正在寻找一款更严肃的微距摄影镜头，并且更喜欢以更大的灵活性进行手持拍摄，请选择其中一款中端镜头。
  • 最后，如果你想拍摄昆虫或者想要完美的图像质量，请选择长微距镜头。

在 Lightroom 中编辑月亮照片的基本技巧一文首先出现在Digital Photography School上。它的作者是西蒙·林斯穆斯 (Simon Ringsmuth) 。

您可以拍摄的最引人注目的照片之一是清晰的满月照片。美丽的月亮图像不需要很多奇特的装备，但你必须在正确的时间出现在正确的地点。更棘手的是，每年你只有很少的机会尝试登月（假设你想捕捉明亮的满月，就是这样！）。

不过，拍摄照片只是一个开始。如果您想让您的月球照片脱颖而出，那么花一些时间处理每个文件就很重要。您不必进行大量调整，但即使是一些小的调整也可以发挥很大作用。在本文中，我将分享简单的 Lightroom 月亮编辑技巧，让您的照片闪闪发光！

1.以RAW格式拍摄

从技术上讲，这并不是在 Lightroom 中编辑月球照片的技巧，但在处理文件时它会产生如此大的变化，值得一提。

RAW 相对于 JPEG 等有损格式的优势已得到充分证明。虽然 JPEG 格式有时很有用，但 RAW 对于拍摄月球照片至关重要。您需要拥有足够的编辑余地来调整颜色、曝光和其他参数，而这正是未压缩 RAW 格式的突出之处。

例如，下面的照片可能看起来不太像，但它是大多数人使用一些基本相机设备拍摄的月球照片的相当典型：

我用作物传感器相机拍摄了上面的照片，这比昂贵的全画幅型号更常见。我也只变焦到 200 毫米——这就是我的镜头的极限！ – 许多套装变焦镜头都可以轻松达到这一点。

乍一看，我在这里似乎无能为力。月亮曝光过度，有点模糊。它太小了，电源线直接穿过框架。此外，天空有一种奇怪的蓝色，有点不自然。

然而，一切并没有失去！借助 RAW 文件的强大功能，再加上 Lightroom 中的一点编辑能力，这张照片可以变成值得相框的图像。

2.不要害怕裁剪

早在数码摄影的早期，人们经常争论百万像素的重要性。一个常见的说法是更多的百万像素等于更好的照片。虽然这不一定是真的，但拥有更高的百万像素数确实可以为您提供更多的裁剪空间，这在您的拍摄对象较远时非常有用（对于月球而言，为 239,000 英里！）。

如今大多数相机的像素都超过 24 兆像素，这为您提供了很大的自由度来裁剪照片。如果您没有巨大的长焦变焦镜头来放大单个月球陨石坑，请改用 Lightroom。 裁剪你的图像，直到它漂亮而紧密，月亮位于中心，就像我在这个 Lightroom 屏幕截图中所做的那样：

在上面的示例中，我将图像裁剪得足够紧，以去除除了月亮和天空之外的所有内容。电线和树木都消失了，只剩下灿烂的月亮。即使进行如此大的裁剪，生成的图像仍为 4.3 兆像素 - 足以制作像样的 8×10 打印，尤其是考虑到观看距离时。

3.调整白平衡

在这一点上，我的示例月球照片更好，但还有很长的路要走。 （如果您跟随自己的一张照片，那么您很可能处于同一条船上！）

下一步是调整白平衡。我建议在裁剪月球照片后执行此操作的原因是，裁剪可以帮助您仅关注图像的重要部分。如果您在裁剪前调整白平衡，则可能会将编辑集中在裁剪后丢弃的图像部分上。

调整月球照片白平衡的方法没有正确或错误之分。这完全取决于您希望最终图像的外观以及您希望观众看到它时的感受。如果您不确定如何继续，并且想要一个对月球照片进行白平衡的良好起点，我推荐以下两个选项：

  1. 使用日光预设，或者
  2. 使用白平衡滴管并单击月亮。

下一张图片显示了这两种白平衡技术的效果：

正如您所看到的，这些方法产生了截然不同的结果。

您还可以使用“温度”和“色调”滑块，直到获得您喜欢的外观。需要记住的一件事是，月亮本身不产生光；它会产生光。它只是一个从天而降的岩石球。您看到的光是从表面反射的阳光，这就是为什么有些人更喜欢使用适合阳光的白平衡。不过，选择权在您手中，您可以根据需要设置白平衡。

另一种选择是结合多种方法。单击月亮上的吸管工具，然后使用遮罩仅更改月亮的白平衡。这将使天空呈现丰富的深蓝色，而月亮呈现黄色。

使用标准画笔，获得自然的外观可能有点棘手。如果做得不好，你会在月球边缘看到奇怪的彩色光环。然而，Lightroom 的“选择对象”选项对于遮盖月亮非常有效，仅此而已！

4.调整曝光

拍摄月亮时确定曝光是很棘手的。这是一个巨大的明亮球体，映衬在黑暗的天空中，这意味着许多传统的曝光建议并不适用。我通常更喜欢将月亮曝光不足，然后在 Lightroom 中调整色调。这样，我就可以保留亮点。

您也可以使用这种方法。然而，如果您希望在现场获得准确的曝光，那么值得记住的是，如果您的照片有点曝光过度，如果您以 RAW 格式拍摄，仍然可以恢复细节。

在我展示的示例中，我的镜头曝光过度大约一档。为了解决这个问题，我将在Lightroom Basic 面板的曝光滑块中输入 -0.75 值。这使一切都变暗：月亮和天空。如果您希望天空保持相同的亮度水平，同时仅减少月球上的曝光，请使用“高光”滑块。向左拖动它可以降低月亮的亮度，同时保持天空完好无损。

调整曝光并不是最令人着迷的月球编辑技巧之一，但这是使您的最后一枪看起来不错的重要步骤。

5.施加质地并锐化

当您拍照时，您必须与各种变量抗衡，这些变量可能会导致柔软或模糊的外观。我们看到月亮穿过数英里的大气，通常包含灰尘和其他颗粒。您的镜头可能也不是粘性的，尤其是当您使用作为相机套件一部分的变焦镜头时。

令人高兴的是，Lightroom可以使用一些简单的滑块来处理这些问题！

在大多数后处理的情况下，我建议从锐化的滑块开始，但不要在编辑月球时。在这种情况下，您想带出月亮的质地和表面细节，因此纹理滑块实际上是更好的起点。 （您可以在基本面板的底部找到它。）

另外，如果您希望在编辑中更精确，则可以选择性地将纹理添加到月球上。

锐化的滑块也派上用场，但是在调整纹理后，用于微调图像。但是，我不建议使用Clarity Slider 。这将带有月球射击的错误，不自然的外观，并且也会在天空中揭示一些不必要的噪音。

添加您的最后一笔！

此时，您应该有一张精美的月亮照片。您可以选择导出图像以共享，也可以应用一些额外的调整以抛光图像。

如果您想添加一些完成修饰，那么您有很多选择。我建议以下一些调整：

  • 添加一个小插图
  • 使用掩蔽工具降低天空中的噪音
  • 调整音调曲线以具有非常小的S形
  • 提高或降低蓝色饱和度
  • 将您的图片转换为黑白

当谈到月亮编辑技巧时，天空实际上是极限。这些应该足以让您开始，但是我建议您花时间尝试使用Lightroom中的一些滑块来看看您可以做什么。

帖子摄影的音调范围是什么？首先出现在数字摄影学校。它由亚当·韦尔奇（Adam Welch）撰写。

音调范围的概念对于每个图像都是基础的。但对于许多摄影师来说，色调范围被忽视和忽视。

当我们在特定的道路上前进时，有时即使是最细心的人也会认为某些事情是理所当然的。这些简单的元素有时会首先被忽略，例如草率的三脚架设置或误导的摄像头设置。同样，摄影的基本技术概念被误解了，被误解或（甚至更糟！）完全被遗忘。这种疾病跨越了各个层次的技能，并且折磨了职业选手和业余爱好者。

例如，考虑任何图像的最基本构建块：光。每个摄影师都知道，如果没有光，就无法捕捉照片。许多摄影师擅长使用光来创造不同的效果（轮廓，光晕，强烈的阴影等）。

但是，光线产生的不同音调呢？我们的照片显示了光和黑暗之间的对比度，但两者之间的距离几乎是无限的。作为摄影师，我们可以使用对音调范围的理解，即浅色和深色音调之间的距离，以改善我们的图像，这就是我今天想与您讨论的内容。

图像的音调范围是什么？

音调范围是指图像中的亮度度量，从纯黑色到纯白色。我们照片中不同亮度水平之间的距离决定了对比度。

看看这个音调：

我们从左侧（黑色）的完整黑暗移动到右侧的光线（白色）。摄影师通常使用这种量表 - 将其分为黑色，阴影，中间色调，亮点和白色 - 通常用于讨论其图像中的音调区域。请注意，它同时适用于颜色和黑白照片（尽管考虑彩色照片时，您需要在心理上将颜色色调与基础色调分开）。

现在，让我们谈谈每个价值观以及它们与您的摄影的关系。

强调

很长一段时间以来，我认为亮点是图像中最亮的部分。但这不是很好！实际上，亮点是由高亮度（亮度）值组成的照片的区域，但仍包含可辨别的细节。

这是突出显示亮度值的一个示例（高光区域用红色箭头表示）：

白人

如果将照片的亮度提高到亮点被吹出的程度（细节是看不见的），则您已经达到了音调范围的“白色”部分。

即使您的照片的白色区域没有看起来白色，由于缺乏细节，它也可能被视为白色区域。以下是图像中白人的示例：

中间

Midtones是 - 您猜对了！ - 在中间。换句话说，所有不是黑暗或光的亮度值都被认为是中间的。在下一个图像中，许多云以及马的灰色部分落入了Midtone地区：

阴影

作为阴影的区域与高光的直接相反。因此，阴影是照片的区域，但仍然保留了一定程度的细节。

黑人

零亮度的照片的任何部分都被认为是黑色的。就像较早的完整白色区域一样，我们图像中的这些点不必完全没有颜色即可被视为纯黑色。

什么音调范围是理想的？

如果您曾经见过一群摄影师之间就照片中最佳音调范围的对话，那么您会发现意见分歧。

一些摄影师认为图像不应包含完整的黑色或完整白色的区域。这些人认为，为了获得最佳结果，照片的所有部分都应为观众提供一定程度的细节。换句话说，最好的照片没有极端的音调范围，从纯黑色到纯白色。相反，音调范围保持略有压缩。

但是，其他摄影师认为，为了对比，燃烧或吹出一些亮度值是完全可以的。这样做意味着最终镜头将具有完整的黑色和完整白色的区域，并且所有其他亮度值都落在这两个绝对之间。这样的照片的音调范围非常宽。

虽然确实希望向听众传递最大的视觉信息，但并非总是如此。有时候，您需要将照片带回家所需的东西，或者烧毁的阴影或爆炸的亮点。

使用音调范围来改善照片！

我认为，没有一个完美的音调范围可以在每张照片中应用。相反，这取决于场景以及您的创造力。

但是，重要的是，您始终记住在拍摄和处理图像时的音调范围概念。这似乎是一个简单的想法，但是很容易忽略不同级别亮度如何影响图像的重要性。

这是照片中的音调区域的快速分解：

  • 亮点：照片中仍然保持细节的明亮区域
  • 白人：绝对没有信息的极端亮度区域（细节）
  • 中间点：这些既不是阴影也不是亮点，而是亮度的中间价值
  • 阴影：图像的较暗区域仍然保持细节
  • 黑人：完全烧毁了照片的部分，其中包含绝对没有细节

像摄影中的大多数概念一样，必须充分了解照片中的音调范围。您应该使用这些知识来努力争取技术卓越的发展 - 但您还应该使用它来知道何时打破规则以实现您的创造性愿景。

并置。这是我最喜欢的单词之一，也是成功摄影的最重要方面之一。并置有意识地用于肖像画，户外冒险摄影和旅行拍摄。但是，在景观摄影中，并置经常被忽略。

我说“被忽视”，因为许多景观射击者实际上确实在其景观图像中使用并置。他们只是在不知道它的情况下使用它！您会看到，并置（指将冲突或对比元素汇总在一起的行为）是大多数好景观照片中的关键特征。我并不是说没有意识到并列的景观摄影师不好。相反，我认为许多伟大的景观射击者甚至没有考虑它。

现在，如果您喜欢景观摄影，则可能已经直观地使用并置。但是，一旦您意识到并置如何改善您的图像和经常并列的各种元素，那么您的景观镜头就会变得更好。

这就是我进来的地方。今天，我将分享您可以创建并置的三种基本方法：通过颜色，通过纹理和通过主题。这并不是详尽的可能性清单 - 实际上，我可以列出十几种将此技术应用于您的照片的方法 - 但这是一个很棒的起点！

并置：颜色

您可能熟悉色轮；当您了解初级和次要颜色之间的区别时，您可能会在小学的概念中介绍。最近，如果您使用了一个编辑程序，例如Lightroom，捕获One或Acdsee Photo Studio，则会在各种颜色分级面板中看到色轮。

色轮显示三个圆圈的三种原色（红色，蓝色和黄色）。它还显示了所有颜色混合在它们之间混合在一起的混合物。结果是连续的颜色模糊，几乎涵盖了可见光谱上的所有内容。

当蓝色和黄色，红色和绿色以及橙色和紫色在色轮上相反的颜色将在同一张照片中出现时对比或并置。也就是说，他们会以令人愉悦的方式彼此脱颖而出，有时会以矛盾的方式脱颖而出。您还可以在色轮上创建并置颜色的并置与彼此接近的颜色：红色和橙色，绿色和蓝色，蓝色和紫色。

任何类型的颜色并置都可以在景观摄影中起作用，但是不同类型的并置将会带来不同的结果，并且您需要意识到颜色在图像中相互作用的方式，以确保最终结果是您的意图。

例如，红色和蓝调通常是在景观摄影中融合在一起的：蓝色的水，日落的天空，红色的花朵，蓝天，秋天的颜色在深色的背景下，等等。

颜色在景观摄影中起着重要的作用，一旦看到它们，我们就会意识到令人愉悦的颜色组合。但是认识到为什么他们令人愉悦的原因与注意到他们确实很好。

因此，请在您的作品中寻找这些关系，并专注于它们的位置。像红色这样的颜色在吸引眼睛方面非常有效。但是要最有效，红色通常需要用凉爽的音调来平衡图像。请注意图像中颜色的分布方式。这很重要。

并置：纹理

并置的纹理在任何景观中都很丰富：尖刺的灌木丛与光滑的景观，流过粗糙的岩石，锯齿状的巨石在原本草地的草地中间，等等。对比质地，例如对比色彩，很容易在现场观察。但是，重要的是要考虑如何结合不同的纹理以获得最佳效果。

像明亮而强烈的颜色一样，需要适度使用侵略性的纹理。如果过于自由地使用，尖锐而粗糙的质地将主导着景观图像，与红色和橙子大量出现的方式相同。

也就是说，像压倒性的颜色一样，压倒性的纹理可能正是您想要的。当您制作图像时，请注意该决定。如果您确实决定用侵略性纹理填充景观镜头，请使刺激性的纹理成为图像的点。否则，错误的平衡或侵略性纹理过于偶然地放置，可能会破坏图像的平衡。

当您接近每个新景观场景时，请考虑不同的纹理以及您想讲述的故事。然后将它们相应地放在框架中。

老实说：有效地将纹理并列很难弄清楚。颜色并置可以通过颜色理论来指导，但据我所知，关于纹理没有明确的规则！就是说，虽然您可能并不总是意识到何时正确地平衡纹理，但您肯定会知道什么时候出错。

并置：主题

我的前两种并置 - 颜色和纹理 - 有些模糊，很难有意识地应用在现场。但是在本节中，我想谈谈主题并置。在景观摄影中，主题创建的并置更容易应用，并且几乎总是会增加您的图像兴趣。

当我坐下来写这篇文章时，想到的第一件事是天气。风暴灯是尽管乌云密布的那种罕见的阳光，是主题并列的一个完美例子。很少有东西像暴风雨的一天和阳光一样对比。

将天气与景观的元素联系起来是创建并置的另一种方式。几年前，当我受到罕见的雷暴对待时，我在德克萨斯州大弯国家公园的Chisos山上远足。当短暂的暴风雨清除了山脉时，出现了彩虹。沙漠景观是彩虹在蓝天上，导致不可否认的并置：

并置在景观摄影中与其他任何艺术学科一样重要，即使它更难使用。请注意颜色，纹理和主题在景观图像中相互作用的方式，您一定会找到巨大的成功！

The post How to Make An Inexpensive DIY Light Tent appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Darren Rowse .

Note: This is a great DIY light tent tutorial that we originally published in 2008. Since then, thousands of our readers have used it to build their own DIY tents (with outstanding results!). It's worth mentioning, however, that in the last 15+ years, light tents have become substantially cheaper. You can now purchase an inexpensive light tent on Amazon for around $30 . Of course, DIY models do come with plenty of benefits, and if that's your preferred approach, then read on!

Light tents are a great way to capture images lit by soft, flattering light, and they're used by a wide variety of photographers: product shooters, macro snappers, flower photographers, and more. If you need to photograph (relatively) small subjects and you want to create a consistent white-background effect, then a light tent (also known as a light box) is the perfect tool for the job.

When I was looking to delve into product photography , I was browsing my local photography store, and I came across a pop-up light tent. It consisted – as most light boxes do! – of a collapsible white fabric box with a hole in the front. It also had three lights, which were designed to be positioned around the outside of the box.

I was going to purchase the light tent, but then I saw the $100 price tag. No way was I going to spend $100 on some fabric and three lights when I could do it myself for far less! So I left the store and designed a DIY light tent of my own:

It might not look quite as polished as a store-bought model, but it does a very nice job, and it cost very little.

If you're like me, and you don't want to shell out cash for a light tent that you can build yourself, then this article should help you out. I explain the step-by-step process for constructing your own DIY light tent (and I also offer a few tips so you can make the most of it while shooting !).

Building a DIY light tent: the materials

You don't need to spend much to make your own light tent. Most – or all – of the materials below are probably lying somewhere around your house. Here's what you need:

一个盒子

The box can be any size, though if it's too big, you may have trouble positioning your lights around it. I prefer the box to be as square as possible.

You can purchase boxes, but these days, it's easy to find them for free. I got mine from work – the office was going to throw it out – but you can always repurpose a box from a package delivery.

织物

A light tent should have fabric over all but one of its sides, so make sure you sure you buy enough fabric to cover most of your box.

You want it to be somewhat translucent and neutral in color. For my DIY light tent, I used white muslin fabric, which you can grab from most arts and crafts stores.

Other folks have suggested fabrics such as white nylon and white fleece. If you don't want to spend on fabric and you have some white undershirts lying around, you can even use those; cut up the sides to split each shirt in two. (If you use multiple shirts, be sure that the colors are identical, or your end result may not turn out so nice!)

磁带

I used tape to secure the fabric to the sides of the box. This is especially useful if you want to try out different fabrics. I used regular masking tape, which keeps the fabric in place but is fairly easy to remove and adjust.

白板

This will line the inside of the box and will also serve as a background for your photos. For this, I like to use Bristol board, a heavyweight paper (.006″ thick) designed for drawing/art. White board is ideal for high-key backgrounds, but if you want a different look, you can go for different colors.

I would suggest buying two or three sheets of board as you will be cutting up two to line your box (or more, depending on the size!), and you'll also need one for the background.

胶水

This is to stick the lining in the box. You can use a glue stick for this. Another option is spray adhesive.

灯

A light tent won't work so well without lights. If you don't already have the right type of lights lying around, this will be the most expensive part of your DIY setup.

In my opinion, lighting is the most important part of this box. Without it, you won't get the picture you desire. When building my box, I went to my local hardware store and picked up some daylight bulbs. I don't recommend using more conventional light bulbs – these will create a yellow color cast. I purchased 90-watt compact fluorescent bulbs, which didn't cost a lot and did the job well. Basically, any full-spectrum light bulbs will do.

You'll also want to obtain a lighting fixture. If you have one of those desk lamps, it'll work fine. If you don't have a light fixture that you can use, I'd suggest getting a clamp-on work light.

Miscellaneous tools

Last, you'll want to make sure you have a few standard household tools on hand: a sharpie marker, a tape measure, a straight-edge ruler, scissors, and a knife.

The step-by-step process for building a light tent

Now that you have your materials, it's time to build your tent! The process is fairly easy, so you shouldn't have much trouble, even if you're not much of a DIY person. When you're done, you'll be able to take clean and crisp shots, like this:

Step 1: Mark your box

Place the box face up, so the open flaps are at the top. You'll need to mark a two-inch border along the edges of the four box faces (ie, all but the top and the bottom).

So using your tape measure and sharpie, mark several points 2 inches from the side of the box along every edge. When you're done, you should see a spotted border:

Then use your straight-edge ruler to connect all the points. That should give you a nice-looking square/rectangle in the middle of the box with a two-inch border around it.

(Again, leave the top and the bottom of the box alone!)

Step 2: Cut out the boxes

Next, cut out the boxes that you've drawn. Do this on all four main sides of the box, avoiding the top and the bottom.

When you're done, cut off the flaps on the top of the box. Leave the bottom intact.

Step 3: Line the box with Bristol board

We want to create liners for all of the exposed cardboard inside the box. Therefore, you'll want to cut 16 strips from your Bristol board. The length of the strips will need to match the box dimensions.

Take your strips of Bristol board, then glue them into the box. If you applied marker to the Bristol board before cutting, make sure the marks are against the cardboard so they can't be seen. Here's what you should have at this point in the process:

Step 4: Add the background

Now it's time to give the box a backdrop. Take another piece of Bristol board and cut it so the width is the same as the inside of the box. The length should be much longer than the box, however!

Place the long piece of Bristol board into the box so that the piece curves to the bottom, like so:

Avoid creasing the board as this will show up in your photo. Cut off any excess paper that is sticking out the top.

Step 5: Add the fabric

All that's left is to prepare the fabric and secure it to your light tent! First, cut the fabric into squares/rectangles to cover three of the open sides. Next, cut a big piece that's capable of completely covering the top of the box.

Finally, tape the fabric so all the holes in the box are covered, except the front hole (ie, the hole that faces the background). Tape the top piece on, too.

Here's the result:

And you're done! Now all you have to do is light the box, place a subject inside, and start snapping away! The most basic one-light setup that I recommend involves placing your light above the box so it's pointed down:

But there are many variations you can do to get the photo you want. If you light your subject from above but are noticing strong shadows, try positioning additional lights on the other sides of the box.

Don't be afraid to get very close to your subject, even if that means putting your camera partially inside the box:

If you're interested in creating those ultra-bright, high-key backdrops that are popular in product photography, post-processing programs can be a big help. You may need to brighten the whites and/or the highlights until you get the look you want.

Here's my DIY light tent in action:

And here's another example image:

Capture some top-notch product photos!

Well, there you have it! As you should now be aware, creating a nice light box is pretty darn easy.

So go make your light box. Test it out on some fun subjects. Pretty soon, you'll be creating the kind of product photos that belong on a website!

Now over to you:

This article was updated in May 2024 with contributions from Stacey Hill and Jaymes Dempsey.

For the longest time, the Canon EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro lens was on my “want” list. Oddly, when I finally did buy it, I didn't use it all that frequently, and it sat in the cupboard, just gathering dust, for a couple of years.

But that didn't last. These days, the Canon 100mm f/2.8L Macro is my absolute favorite lens. It's my go-to model for doing still life, food, and, of course, macro photography.

Below, I share my practical, hands-on review of the Canon 100mm Macro. I don't spend time on specifications and studio tests; instead, I focus on what the lens is like to work with in the field. I explain why I think it's so special, I discuss how I personally use it, and I share a lot of example photos (all taken with the lens). I also delve into its pros and cons. That way, if you're thinking of purchasing the 100mm f/2.8L Macro but you're not quite sure whether it's worth the (somewhat steep) price, you'll be able to make an informed decision.

让我们开始吧！

What's so great about the Canon EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro?

Sharpness, image quality, color, and versatility – the Canon 100mm Macro has it all!

When I use this lens, I know that it'll pick up absolutely every detail, assuming I use a sufficiently fast shutter speed and I nail the focus exactly. In other words, when this lens is sharp, it's crystal clear.

Unfortunately, due to the combined weight of the lens (625 g) on my Canon 7D Mark II , I find it difficult to handhold and get crisp shots. So I use the 100mm f/2.8L Macro on a tripod to maintain stability and to guarantee the focus is bang on.

This lens has a richness to the colors that I appreciate – it gives the best color reproduction of any of my lenses. Also when I shoot at its widest maximum aperture of f/2.8, the soft background blur is wonderfully creamy!

Finally, the Canon 100mm f/2.8L is designed as a macro lens (and it offers a 1:1 magnification ratio). Given the macro focus, its versatility is impressive. I use the lens for an array of genres: macro photography , food photography , flower photography , and still-life photography . I don't do a lot of portrait shooting , myself, but it's also a favorite lens for portrait photographers due to the telephoto focal length, beautiful background bokeh, wide maximum aperture, and incredible sharpness.

This lens is quiet, it's fast, and it's a lovely lens to use. Once I mastered the art of precise focusing with a really tiny depth of field and was able to consistently get sharp shots, the quality of the images impressed me more and more.

How I use my Canon EF 100mm f/2.8L lens

In this section, I focus on my personal use of the 100mm Macro lens, and I do my best to explain how I work with it to get nice photos.

1. Food photography

Working with natural light in my home studio sometimes means the light is not always abundant . And even when the light is bright, I often need to filter it quite heavily so I don't blow out the highlights on parts of the food I'm photographing (such as whipped cream or icing). I've found that working in slightly less-than-ideal light conditions is where this lens really comes into its own.

The 100mm f/2.8L's maximum aperture captures a lot of light, and I'm able to maintain a reasonable shutter speed even in these low-light conditions. While I do sometimes bump up the ISO a small amount, it's not enough to affect the quality of the image.

Additionally, given this lens's incredible optics combined with the excellent magnification capabilities, I can capture the finest small details, which really add character to food shots taken with this lens. Water droplets on fruit or the tiny hairs on a raspberry become things of wonder, brought into view by this lens's impressive clarity!

2. Flower photography

Earlier in this article, I mentioned how, after purchasing the Canon 100mm Macro, I didn't use it right away. Well, flower photography is what finally forced me to get my Canon 100mm lens out of storage and onto my camera! I had become interested in still-life photography, and I was basing my compositions around flowers as main subjects.

As it turned out, this lens is spectacular for photographing flowers. Since you can focus so close, flowers offer many opportunities to be creative with this lens. You can shoot the whole flower, move in to shoot just a few petals, or highlight ultra-tiny details.

The 100mm Macro's lovely color and soft background bokeh are perfect for flower photography, and I enjoy using the lens with a wide maximum aperture. It is a lot of fun to experiment with areas of selective focus and use the shallow depth of field in unexpected ways.

3. Macro photography

There is a whole world of things too small for our eyes to see naturally that suddenly become revealed when we shoot with a macro lens. It is fascinating to uncover tiny details in everyday objects, and that's yet another area where the Canon 100mm f/2.8L Macro performs beautifully.

Creating abstracts using textures or just exploring the details on small items is possible with this 100mm Macro lens. The ordinary becomes extraordinary when you can get up close and personal.

The toughest part of using macro lenses at high magnifications is the technical side of things; even with narrower apertures, you'll have an ultra-thin depth of field, and at such high magnifications, you'll also struggle with blur to camera shake.

I don't like to handhold this lens for those exact reasons. When I use this lens, my camera is mounted on my tripod – and I know that I can get sharp focus with a very narrow depth of field on a small subject.

4. Other genres

I am not a portrait photographer, but I do have cats, and they are fun to shoot with this lens as it picks up so much detail.

Again, I personally struggle to successfully handhold my DSLR with this lens and get sharp images, so I don't shoot with it off my tripod very often. But you don't have to use this lens at high magnifications, and when you take several steps back for a wider perspective, handholding the 100mm Macro is a lot easier.

Canon EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro specifications

This is a practical review, so I don't want to focus on technical specifications. However, here's a quick list of specs to keep in mind:

  • EF mount for Canon full-frame DSLRs
  • 100mm focal length
  • f/2.8 maximum aperture
  • Weight: 625 g
  • 1:1 maximum magnification ratio
  • 0.99 ft/300mm closest focusing distance
  • Image stabilization for handheld shooting

Canon EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro review: final words

After using this lens extensively, here's my breakdown of pros and cons:

优点

  • Extremely sharp
  • Ultra-shallow depth of field
  • Bokeh is smooth
  • Beautiful color reproduction
  • Decent image stabilization
  • Compatible with Canon full-frame and APS-C DSLRs; can be used with Canon RF-mount cameras via an adapter
  • 1:1 maximum magnification
  • Comes with a lens hood and carry bag

缺点

  • Heavy and can be difficult to handhold
  • 昂贵的
  • 300mm minimum focus distance means you have to get reasonably close to your subject for a life-size reproduction

I love the Canon 100mm f/2.8L Macro, and for me, the pros of shooting with this lens far outweigh the cons. Yes, it can be difficult to handhold effectively, especially at high magnifications, but that's where a tripod saves the day.

For photographers looking to get high-quality photos of small subjects – whether that's food items, flowers, jewelry, tiny products, or something else – this lens is a great choice. And since the optics are so incredible and the bokeh is so creamy, you can also use it for more conventional subjects, such as portraits and landscapes.

Photos with a vintage look evoke the appearance of faded prints captured decades ago.复古效果图像通常包括由胶片引起的色偏，并且它们（理想情况下）给观看者一种怀旧感。

But while vintage processing effects are popular – if you spend a few minutes scrolling through Instagram, you're bound to hit upon a vintage image! – there's not a specific vintage look that all photographers agree on.

In this article, I'm going to explain how you might go about creating a vintage look in Lightroom . However, it's important to bear in mind that my idea of a vintage look might not be the same as yours. Before you continue reading, I'd recommend spending a few minutes determining what characteristics you think a vintage photo should have; that way, you can tweak my suggestions to fit your vision.

Okay, are you ready to continue? Let me start by explaining my version of a vintage look: Photos with a vintage edit are nostalgic and faded. There may be a color cast or faded blacks, and the images should look like they were taken on film. Here's one of my photos that I've edited in Lightroom to look vintage:

Now that we're on the same page, let me share several approaches for producing that vintage look!

Creating a vintage look with Lightroom presets

If you came here in the hopes of learning how to create a vintage look yourself, don't worry. In the second part of this article, I explain how you can create a vintage look from scratch! But I think it's wise to acknowledge that sometimes the easiest path is to let someone else do the hard work of figuring out the mechanics and then just buy into their expertise.

Yes, you can create a vintage look manually – but if you're not an experienced editor, it might be easier to buy Lightroom presets or even download some free ones. There are plenty of great vintage-effect presets out there, and when you get a preset pack, you generally end up with a handful of different looks that you can apply to your images. That way, you don't have to spend lots of time testing out different edits until you find the one you like; you can simply click on a few vintage presets, hit on a good result, make a few additional tweaks as needed, and then call it a day.

This comparison shows you some of the effects you can create with Lightroom presets:

In fact, all of the presets used for the image above were downloaded for free! They're a little heavy-handed, but that's okay; I think the best way to use Lightroom presets is as a starting point . Once you have applied the preset, you can then go to the right-hand panels and tweak the editing settings to get the most out of your photo.

(I haven't done that with these examples as I wanted to show you the type of results you can expect straight out of the box.)

The best free vintage presets for Lightroom

There are lots of high-quality free presets available online, and while these tend to be more hit-and-miss than paid presets, they're certainly worth checking out.

For instance, Preset Love offers 16 different free vintage Lightroom presets to download, including options geared toward portraits, architecture, and landscape photography.

Parker Photographic has a nice set of 10 free retro presets (though to download them, you'll need to scroll down past the sales text until you find the “10 Free Retro Presets” heading).

And this Vintage Grain preset from Illumelation is also very cool.

The best paid vintage presets for Lightroom

Not everybody wants to pay for Lightroom presets, but there are certainly some great preset collections out there. I recommend (and have personally bought and used) the following:

Nicole S. Young's Vintage Fade presets . These are the least expensive out of all these preset packs. The set includes Photoshop and ACR presets as well as Lightroom Classic presets.

Lightgram Instafade presets . These presets emulate the beauty and nostalgia of film. I like Lightgram's presets a lot!

Really Nice Images Faded Films presets . These presets are far more expensive than the others, but you get nearly twice as many presets plus a toolkit to help you tweak the settings. Most importantly, they are ridiculously good.

Here's a comparison showing some of these paid presets in action:

How to manually create a vintage look in Lightroom

With that out of the way, it's time to look at a few techniques you can use to create the vintage look yourself in Lightroom.

Note that you'll want to start each edit the way you would start any edit: crop to improve the composition, apply lens corrections, adjust the tone sliders to handle any exposure problems, apply white balance corrections, etc. Basically, get to a point where your image looks nice but stylistically neutral.

Then you can proceed with the following stylistic edits:

1. Add a fade with the tone curve

Scroll down to the Tone Curve panel , then click on the point in the bottom left-hand corner (ie, the left end of the curve). Drag the end of the curve upward:

This removes true black from the photo, making the darkest tones lighter to produce a fade effect. How far you lift the curve is up to you. The best way is to watch your image as you apply the fade, then simply stop when you like the result.

You'll get the best results when the curve starts from a linear position – that is, when it's a straight line from bottom-left to top-right rather than a true curve.

To complement the fade effect, you might scroll up to the Basic panel and reduce the Saturation or Vibrance slider to reduce the colors in your shot.

Another way to fade the blacks is by manually adding three points to the curve (each about a quarter of the way along), and then lifting the left-hand corner:

This still fades the blacks, but it adjusts the rest of the image less, and the look is slightly different. Experiment with both techniques to see which one suits your particular photo best.

This is how those curve adjustments look when applied to my example photo:

Note that using the standard RGB Point Curve applies this fade/matte effect without directly adjusting the colors in your image. However, you can play with the color curves as well. If you use the same fade technique with a color curve, it affects the color of the photo as well as the contrast.

Here are a couple of examples:

There's a lot you can do with the Tone Curve panel, and we've only really scratched the surface here. Once you get the hang of the basic fade effect, feel free to try out other adjustments, especially those that include color grades!

2. Apply a split tone in the Color Grading panel

Another way to add a vintage color cast to an image is with split toning . The basic concept is simple: You apply a warm color to the highlights (such as orange, red, or yellow) and a cool one to the shadows (such as blue, dark green, or teal). You may be aware that warm colors appear to move toward the viewer and cooler colors appear to move away . Split toning builds on that principle to add greater depth/dimensionality to your photos.

Applying a split-toning effect is easy in Lightroom. Just scroll down to the Color Grading panel :

Then adjust the Shadows and Highlights wheels until you get the effect you desire. Like I said, for a vintage look, it can be a good idea to choose a warmer color for the highlights and a cooler color for the shadows:

Though for a more uniform color cast, you can tweak only the Midtones wheel while leaving the Shadows and Highlights wheels untouched. That can be a simple way to give your image a strong film-like color cast.

In this next example, you can see how the split tone added to my vintage effect:

Try out some vintage edits!

Now that you know how to create a vintage look using Lightroom, go try it for yourself! Practice working with the tone curve, apply some split-tone effects, and see how you like the results.

The two approaches that I've shared are simple, but they'll go a long way toward achieving that filmic, faded look. Of course, as I emphasized at the start of the article, your understanding of the “vintage” look may be different from my own. If you're not completely satisfied with the adjustments I shared, see if you can use them as a starting point from which you create your own personal vintage effect!

This is a review of the Nikon AF-S FX Nikkor 24-70mm f/2.8G ED lens , which I've used frequently. However, it is not a technical review. I don't spend lots of time discussing specifications, nor do I include resolution charts or autofocusing tests.

Instead, I focus on how this lens performs , and on its strong and weak points. I also share plenty of photos I've taken with the lens. Many will be edited in Photoshop, while others will be straight out of the camera; I include labels on the edited images so you know the difference.

Ready for a hands-on review of the Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G? Let's dive right in!

An overview of the Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G ED

The Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G ED is regularly referred to as one of the best midrange zoom lenses that Nikon ever made. That sounds like a crazy statement, but when you look at the images produced by this lens, you can understand why.

In my view, this is a perfect all-around lens. In fact, once you get your hands on this lens, you may find that you keep it on your camera most of the time. Not only does it have a really good focal range for everyday photography, but it's also a good travel lens. I've heard many photographers say that the 24-70mm f/2.8G was the only lens they took on vacation and it worked great.

Here's a quick look at the technical specifications:

  • Focal length: 24-70mm
  • Mount: Nikon F-mount (can be used on Nikon Z-mount cameras with the FTX adapter)
  • Format: Full frame (can be used on a Nikon APS-C body, but will be cropped)
  • Maximum aperture: f/2.8
  • Minimum aperture: f/22
  • Dimensions: 83mm (diameter) x 133mm (length)
  • Weight: 900 g
  • Zoom ratio: 2.9X
  • Minimum focusing distance: 38 cm

Photography genres where this lens shines

Not sure if the Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G is right for you? Here are the five genres that it works great for:

1. Landscape photography

The Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G isn't considered an ultra-wide-angle lens, but at 24mm on a full-frame sensor, you will get a viewing angle of 84 degrees. This is a pretty wide angle of view, and you can use it to capture beautiful landscape images .

But I recommend this lens for landscape photography for several additional reasons.

First, the Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G boasts beautifully made glass elements that handle light beautifully. There is some distortion at 24mm, but it's easily corrected in Photoshop.

Second, the lens is really sharp. In fact, I think it makes images seem almost too sharp! If you use a tripod and you properly focus your Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G, you may find that you won't need to do much sharpening during post-processing, simply because the optics are so great.

The color rendition on this lens is great, too; as you can see in the example images, the colors are wonderfully vibrant.

Bottom line: This lens is good for landscapes. It's not necessarily a great dedicated landscape photography lens – the 24mm wide end is a little longer than what many landscape photographers look for – but it can certainly perform well for this type of photography.

2. People photography

The Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G lens can work well for people photography , including portraiture, weddings, and events. The focal length flexibility makes it easy to zoom in and out as needed, and the wide maximum aperture allows you to work indoors without too much trouble.

When photographing human subjects, you want to capture minimal perspective distortion, especially when doing portraits. Therefore, if you plan to use the 24-70mm for people photography, I do recommend generally shooting at 50mm and upward .

Note: With a wide-open aperture, you'll be able to effectively isolate your subject and generate a soft, out-of-focus background. The bokeh on this lens is good – more on that later!

3. Close-up and macro photography

While this 24-70mm model is not a macro lens , it has a 37 cm (14.5 in) minimum focusing distance. That may not sound impressive, but at 70mm, you can get pretty close to your subject.

If you are shooting on a high-resolution sensor, you will be able to crop in quite a bit, so you'll be able to produce some really nice close-up images, like this one here:

Again, the Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G is not a dedicated macro lens. However, if you want to get in close to a subject, it can do that. The sharpness and clarity are both amazing, which helps you highlight lots of little details, and even if you're not a serious macro shooter, having close-up capabilities in your back pocket often comes in handy!

4. Street photography

Street photographers traditionally use prime lenses for their work. (Take a look at the setup of a serious street photographer, and you'll often see a 35mm f/1.8, a 50mm f/1.8, or an 85mm f/1.8 lens.)

Sometimes, however, it's good to have a little more flexibility, and the 24-70mm is perfect for this. You can shoot at 35mm, 50mm, or 70mm, and you will get great results each time. Plus, depending on your creative vision and the scene in question, you can shoot anywhere from f/2.8 on up.

Another big selling point of this lens for street photographers: it has a Silent Wave Motor (SWM), which means the autofocus is quick and quiet. There is some vignetting when the lens is used wide open at f/2.8, but I actually think this adds some depth and contrast to street photography images.

5. Travel photography

When planning a photography trip – or simply a vacation that includes some shooting time – you'll always need to consider which lenses to pack and which lenses to leave at home. Weight is always a consideration. Space matters, too.

Fortunately, many photographers view the 24-70mm as a perfect travel lens . At 24mm, you can capture some great images of wide open spaces; you can also easily capture the interiors of churches and cathedrals. Zoom in to 50mm or even 70mm, and you can get pretty close to your subject. Step in even closer , and you can capture some wonderful cameo and detail shots.

The 24-70mm is almost designed for travel photography. Yes, it lacks a little on the long end – 70mm doesn't give you a ton of magnification power – but you will come home with bright, sharp, color-filled images!

How the Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G performs

I've already touched on many of the Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G's major benefits, but I do want to give a quick rundown of the lens's performance:

1. Autofocus

This lens focuses quickly and accurately. I use it on an older DSLR – the Nikon D800 – and it works really well. You can, of course, choose to focus manually, but I would only suggest doing that when shooting landscapes or close-up scenes. If you have a subject that is moving, autofocus is necessary, and the 24-70mm f/2.8 will do a solid job.

2. Optics

The Nikon 24-70mm has amazing optics. It is sharp throughout the zoom range, and while you can expect a bit of vignetting at f/2.8, it's nothing that you can't deal with in Lightroom or Photoshop. It also produces good color, which is vibrant and rich.

When the lens is zoomed out to 24mm, you will see some barrel distortion. Once you zoom in, however, the distortion goes away, so you only really need to watch for it when working at the wide end. Plus, as with the vignetting issue mentioned above, this barrel distortion is easily fixed in Photoshop or Lightroom, so don't be overly concerned about it.

3. Bokeh

Many lenses are judged not only on how sharp they are but also on how smooth and creamy they render out-of-focus areas.

In this area, the 24-70mm does a decent job. To get high-quality background blur (ie, bokeh), you'll need to zoom out to 70mm or get very close to your subject; you'll also need to use a wide aperture such as f/2.8. In my view, the bokeh on this lens is not breathtaking, but it is smooth and soft. The bokeh is not perfect, but it is acceptable, especially when you consider how much this lens offers.

4. Handling

The 24-70mm f/2.8G is quite large and heavy. This is because the wide maximum aperture requires larger glass elements, and the body of the lens is metal. It is a durable lens and can take some rough handling, but be careful – it's an expensive lens, so you don't want to take it for granted.

On its own, the lens is around 900 g. When mounted to my Nikon D800 without a battery back, the combined weight of the lens and camera body is around 2 kg (4.4 lb). That's a fair amount of weight to carry around, and while you can certainly use this lens handheld for long periods, it's something to bear in mind.

The Nikon 24-70mm f/2.G ED: verdict

This 24-70mm lens has been praised as one of the best lenses Nikon ever made, and after using it, I can see why. It's a great addition to any photography bag, and you may find that you keep it on your camera most of the time.

It's tack-sharp, the wide maximum aperture is impressive, and the focal length flexibility is so useful. It's a perfect all-around, everyday lens, though it's also great for professional purposes.

Now, the 24-70mm f/2.8G ED's specifications do come with significant costs, so it's not cheap. It can also be harder to find now that Nikon has shifted to its Z-mount mirrorless lineups, though you shouldn't have any trouble finding used copies.

When considering the price, just remember that you should invest in your lenses. They will generally outlast your camera bodies, and if you look after them, you'll have them for many years. This is one of those lens types; you can count on it to produce great images for many years.

但在一系列功能强大的 Photoshop 工具中，修补工具绝对是我最喜欢的工具之一。 Not only is it helpful in a wide variety of scenarios, it's so easy to use, even for folks with limited Photoshop experience. And with each version of Photoshop, it just seems to get better.

Below, I explain everything you need to know about the Patch tool, including how it works, how to use it, and how to adjust your settings for optimal results. So if you're seeking to understand what the Patch tool is capable of, or you want an effective way to fix problematic areas of your photos, then keep reading!

What does the Patch tool do?

The Patch tool is part of Photoshop's set of healing tools, all of which are designed for retouching and repairing your images. It's primarily used to repair larger areas of an image or to get rid of any distractions or blemishes.

The tool was introduced into Photoshop at the same time as the Healing Brush . It is similar to the Healing Brush tool in that it matches the texture, lighting, and shading of the sampled pixels to the source area. However, the Patch Tool uses selection-defined areas instead of a brush.

(Note: Prior to Photoshop CS6, you could not work on a separate empty layer when using the Patch tool, in contrast to the Spot Healing Brush tool and the Healing Brush tool. This meant that, to use the Patch tool, you had to duplicate the layer that you were working on. However, in Photoshop CS6, the content-aware setting was introduced to the Patch tool, and you can now work on an image using an empty layer. This has made it quite powerful indeed!)

What makes the Patch tool unique is that each time you use it, you'll get a slightly different result – even on the same selection. As I mentioned above, it is great for retouching larger areas of your image, and it'll do this very fast and quite seamlessly.

For instance, my image of a ruddy turnstone looks decent, but there is some debris on the concrete that I would ideally like to remove:

As you can see in this next image, the Patch tool did a great job of getting rid of the cigarette butts and even the stains on the ground:

It was super quick, too!

Additionally, if you set the Patch tool to its Destination mode, you can use it to duplicate, or clone, the selected area. I rarely use it that way myself, but it's still an option to keep in mind, and I'll illustrate it later on in this article.

Where can you find the Patch tool?

The location of the Patch tool depends on how your version of Photoshop is configured. You might find it hidden behind the Spot Healing Brush tool:

Or it might be clearly visible in the Tools panel:

Regardless, it's signified by a “patch” of fabric.

To get started with the Patch tool, simply click on the Patch icon, then continue with the instructions I share below:

How to use the Patch tool: the basics

Working with the Patch tool is extremely easy. Here's what you do:

  1. Select the Patch tool, then choose Source or Destination in the Options bar at the top of the screen. Note that Source will tell Photoshop to patch the selected portion of the image, while Destination will tell Photoshop to use the selected area to patch a different portion of your image. In general, you'll want to use the Source option, and this is selected by Photoshop by default.
  2. Using your cursor, click and draw to select a portion of your image. The selection process is similar to the Lasso tool, where you draw the selection freehand.
  3. Once you complete your selection, you should see the marching ants appear. Place your cursor inside the selected area, then click and drag it in any direction. You will see a preview of the adjusted image as you drag the cursor.
  4. When you release the cursor, Photoshop will blend pixels from the source and the destination area to create a seamless merged image.
  5. Finally, you can deselect the image by tapping Cmd/Ctrl+D .

Yes, it really is that easy, but you probably won't get a 100% accurate result every time. You may have to make a few attempts. Just make sure you are working on a duplicate background layer or using a separate empty layer rather than your original background layer.

Pro tip: You don't have to use the Patch tool to define a selection. You can use any selection tool and then select the Patch tool.

Before I discuss the Content-Aware setting, I want to demonstrate how the Patch tool can be used with the Destination option to clone an isolated area of your image:

Using the Patch tool to duplicate an area

For this next example, I'm going to use the Patch tool to duplicate a bird so there are two ruddy turnstones in the image. The steps are basically the same as above:

  • Make a selection around the bird.
  • Choose Destination in the Options bar.
  • With the Patch tool selected, position the cursor over the selection and move it into the place where you want the “new” bird to appear.

The Patch tool didn't do a bad job, but if you look closely, the surrounding pixels of the selection haven't blended in so well:

If you run into a similar problem, here's an alternative method for getting a better result once you have made the selection for duplicating an area:

Press Cmd/Ctrl+T . This brings up the free Transform tool. Now move the selection to a new area on the image. Click on the tick box to commit, or press Enter on your keyboard. The selection is still active, as the marching ants are visible around it.

With the Patch tool selected, move the cursor over the selection. Hold down the mouse, move the selection slightly, and then release. You will notice the surrounding pixels are blended better:

How to use the Patch tool with content-aware mode

I like to use the Patch tool in both its normal mode and its content-aware mode. In normal mode, the Patch Tool does a great job with general clean-up. However, when you're working with areas close to the edge of the image, the Patch tool struggles to blend or repair the selection – and that's where the Patch tool in its content-aware mode really shines.

To use the Patch tool in content-aware mode, make sure the tool is selected. Then go to the Options bar and change the Patch: setting from Normal to Content-Aware .

If you want to work using an empty layer above the image, make sure Sample All Layers is checked.

Then use the Patch tool as described in the previous sections of this article!

To better understand how the normal mode differs from the content-aware mode, take a look at this next example, where I tried to remove a golf ball on a tee:

This image was patched using the normal mode:

While the second image was patched using content-aware:

And the result was a whole lot better!

Hopefully, you found this article useful – and you now feel like you can quickly and easily fix your images with the Patch tool.

As I explained, the Patch tool is super simple to work with, and it's a great way to remove unwanted portions of a shot, though you can also use it to clone parts of an image!

So fire up Photoshop and have some fun. Try to remove a blemish or two using the Patch tool. Test out the different modes and see what you think!
